Part A: Using a specific example, describe the representation of African Americans in film or television in the twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The upward mobility of African Americans in the late twentieth century has been depicted on television programs such as The Fresh Prince of Bel Air.

  • African American families are depicted with strong family units on television programs such as Black-ish.

  • Family is represented as very important on shows such as Good Times.

  • Oscar Micheaux presented Black life and characters as realistic and complex in his films.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part B: Describe one way that African Americans contributed to the development of music in the United States.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • African Americans have introduced African-based musical elements to American musical traditions.

  • African American musical traditions such as gospel and blues have influenced rock and roll.

  • The musical tradition of hip-hop developed among young Black and Latino communities in New York.

  • African Americans introduced the banjo to American music.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part C: Describe one way an African American Studies scholar could analyze the representation of African Americans in film and television.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • An African American Studies scholar might take an interdisciplinary approach by analyzing how migration influenced the representation of African Americans in television.

  • An African American Studies scholar might analyze how the Civil Rights movement influenced the representation of African Americans in television and film.

  • An African American Studies scholar might utilize depictions of African Americans in film and television to analyze and understand Black freedom struggles.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.

Part D: Explain one reason why the representation of African Americans in the arts changed after 1900.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The Black Arts movement inspired Black artists and writers to use art as a political tool to achieve Black liberation; for example, Elizabeth Catlett’s Negro es Bello II counters racist ideas by representing Black faces as beautiful.

  • The Great Migration led to many African Americans moving to urban areas in the North; this urban environment fostered creative expression that celebrated Black culture.

  • The New Negro movement inspired artists to challenge racist ideas about Black culture by creating art and literature that celebrated the history and traditions of African Americans.

The response accomplishes the task set by part D of the question.
